description.narrative: Displaced people from Myanmar along the Thai-Myanmar border is prepared and supported for a safe, dignified and voluntary repatriation.

Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med Diakonia om bidrag till "Diakonia's Preparedness for Return Programme for Displaced People of Myanmar and Humanitarian support". Beslutet tas i enlighet med Sidas insatshanteringsregel paragraf 3.11.3.
--------------------
Diakonia har mottagit stöd av Sida för finansiering på 37 000 000 SEK för år 2014 samt 27 500 000 SEK (varav 500 000 SEK öronmärkta för extern utvärdering) för år 2015 till deras program för flyktingar i Thailand och Myanmar, 'Preparedness for Return Programme for Displaced People of Myanmar/Burma and Humanitarian Support'. Diakonia vidareförmedlade en större majoritet till sin partnerorganisation The Border Consortium (TBC), som Diakonia dessutom är styrelsemedlem i.
Insatsen har för avsikt att skapa förbättrade förutsättningar och möjligheter för flyktingar att återvända till Myanmar när detta bedöms säkert. Bland annat avser TBC att bygga kapacitet hos flyktingar i jordbruk och boskapsskötsel, samt att förbättra små företagsägares kapacitet att hantera företag i Myanmar. Vidare avser TBC att bistå med humanitärt stöd, genom främst mat och skydd, till flyktingar som identifieras särskilt utsatta. Det humanitära stödet uppgår till cirka 58 % av TBC:s planerade budget för 2016. Diakonia har också för avsikt att bidra till förbättrad förhållningssätt och kunskap inom TBC:s medlemsorganisationer angående konfliktkänslighet och genus genom kurser, samt genom möten mellan medlemsorganisationer till TBC.
Sida har genom kompletterande insatsbeslut för avsikt att, under förutsättning att riksdagen anvisar nödvändiga finansiella medel, fortsätta stöda Diakonias/TBC:s arbete i ytterligare två år, 10 000 000 SEK för 2016 och 10 000 000 SEK för 2017. Diakonia har för avsikt att fortsatt prioritera det humanitära stödet, men ett ökat fokus, i och med förbättrade omständigheter i Myanmar, kommer att läggas på flyktingars möjlighet till repatriering.
Totala planerade budgeten för TBC för 2016 är ungefär 175,5 MSEK, varav Sidas bistånd genom Diakonia kommer att finansiera minst 5,3 %. Den planerade budgeten förväntas å andra sidan inte finansieras till fullo, vilket innebär att Sidas procentuella andel av den totala slutgiltiga budgeten blir högre. Sida stod under 2015 för cirka 12 % av TBC:s inkomst, och var därigenom den näst största givaren till insatsen efter USA (PRM).
Slutligen bedömer Sida att samtliga medel för 2016 ska utbetalas tidigast möjligt för att på bästa sätt möjliggöra planering och genomförande av den humanitära insatsen utan fördröjning. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
--------------------
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

With this intervention, Diakonia has applied for additional funding from Sida of SEK 10 000 000 for 2016 and SEK 10 000 000 for 2017 for their program with refugees in Thailand and Myanmar, 'Preparedness for Return Program for Displaced People of Myanmar/Burma and Humanitarian Support'. Diakonia will forward the majority of the funding to their partner organization, The Border Consortium (TBC), which Diakonia is also a member of. Diakonia has previously received SEK 37 000 000 for 2014 and 27 500 000 (of which SEK 500 000 were earmarked for an external evaluation) for 2015 for the same intervention.
The proposed action intends to create improved conditions and opportunities for refugees to return to Myanmar when it has been deemed safe. Diakonia proposes through TBC to build capacity among refugees in agriculture and animal husbandry, as well as to improve small business owners' capacity to manage enterprises in Myanmar. Furthermore, Diakonia and TBC will assist with humanitarian support (food and shelter) to refugees identified as vulnerable. The humanitarian support constitutes approximately 58 % of TBC's planned budget in 2016. Diakonia intends to continue contributing in improving TBC's approach to, and knowledge in, conflict sensitivity. Diakonia will take on an active role on the TBC board and will monitor the implementation process through field visits.
The planned total budget for TBC is SEK 175 500 000 in 2016, of which Sida's support through Diakonia will finance 5.3 %. The budget is however not expexted to be fully financed, meaning that the Sida support will constitute a higher percentage of the total budget. In 2015 the Sida support constituted approximately 12 % of TBC's income, making Sida the second biggest donor to the intervention following USA (PRM).

description.narrative: Operational results During the earlier years of the long standing Diakonia/TBC humanitarian programme in Thailand, the focus has mainly been to meet basic humaitarian needs of refugees in the camps in Thailand. These very "hands on"operations have continued during the period 2014-2017. Typical examples of results (from 2017 annual report) for these operational target areas (1-5) are given below: Results area 1: Readiness (for return to Myanmar) - 13 "go and see" visits (to Kayah and Kayin states in Myanmar) were arranged for refugees in Thailand. - Camp information teams reached 70 000 refugees with information on possible future scenarios, including return to Myanmar. Results area 2: Economic and Social Development: - 298 new businesses started (75 % female owned) in nine camps in 2017. In total 2 541 campbusinesses are operating (60% female owned) - 2 642 individuals participated (42% female) in organised agricultural activities -Agricultural productivity was enhanced through improved acces to capital and/or skills for 8 000 people. According to the report, Agriculture and business projects in the area of food security and livelihoods (FSL) showed positive changes in food sources and consumption—the programme supported increases in household production, by building skills and introducing improved practices, as well as facilitating access to land. Results area 3: Humanitarian Support, Food and Shelter: -95 461 refugees received monthly food and charcoal support in nine refugee camps in 2017. -3 022 individuals (92% female) were monthly assisted through the supplementary feeding programme in 2017. -19 196 households received shelter/material assistance during 2017. According to the report, this work consistently makes up almost 70 percent of the total costs of programmes in Thailand and South East Myanmar throughout the programme period. TBC maintained the same level of food assistance for the past two years since the reduction of food rations in 2015, determining that the current ration levels, combined with refugees’ own complementary strategies, provided the minimal acceptable nutritional value In 2016, TBC’s Food Assistance Programme in Thailand broke new ground with the introduction of the Food Card System, an e-voucher programme that allows refugees to buy their own food and promotes decision-making and dignity within communities. Results area 4: Participation and Governance -Karen Human Rights Group published over 100 reports on human rights abuse in 2017 -The Ethnic Nationalities Affairs Centerdid policy consultations with 28 CSO organisations, 17 political parties and 2 ethnic armed groups during 2017. According to the report, the external evaluation commissioned by SIDA and Diakonia, concluded that TBC had been effective and emphasized achievements including the involvement of camp residents in camp management and operations, and the change in TBC’s leadership and governance structure. Diakonia's added value Results area 5: TBC Governance/Quality Assurance: -During 2017 TBC's registration with Myanmars ministry of home affairs was formalised which allows for increased activities on the Myanmar side of the border. According to the report, TBC and the programme went through significant changes during the reporting period. A collaborative working model between the Board and TBC Senior Management Team is now established with monthly senior management reports, including financial reports, shared with the Board for feedback. This has helped ensure that TBC’s performance shows good results in programming. Another result of this collaboration is in the systemization of risk management as well as elaboration of Strategic Plan for 2017-2019 and the Exit Strategy integrated therein. Results Area 6: Conflict Sensitivity/Quality Assurance: - Diakonia has continued its dialogue with TBC Shelter and Settlements specialists to better include conflict sensitivity into the Community driveb Natural Resource management Project (CDNRM). -Diakonia has continued its work to prepare TBC members and other partners for a future scenario where TBCs will close (if camps are closed in Thailand). Many aspects of the work presently done by TBC will need to be continued by partners in order to support refugees - regardless of their physical location. The indicators for this result area have been streamlined from 6 in 2014 to 2 in 2017 as discussion with Sida has led to the agreement that some indicators are outputs and are not good indication of whether the result has been achieved. Results Area 7: Accountability/Quality Assurance -Strengthening of the Beneficiary Complaints and Response Mechanism (BCRM)by introducing new log sheets in order to improve reporting, response and monitoring (of BCRM) on a montly basis. -During 2017 a total of 1 766 camp-based staff received management rtaining on social inclusion, equity, accountability, child protection etc. According to the report, one result of this is that TBC is now more pro-active and systematically taking into account diversity in the camps and encourage every group to engage in preparedness plans. Results area 8: Field Monitoring/Quality Assurance -Diakonia conducted six monitoring visits to camps during 2017 to meet with camp management committees, refugee comittees, camp residents, CBOs and TBC staff. According to the report, compared with the previous programme period, Diakonia improved its monitoring and reporting to SIDA with reports providing a clear and comprehensive picture of TBC’s work, achievements and shortcomings. This is affirmed by the external evaluation team who concluded that Diakonia’s monitoring role has produced important and relevant results. Results area 9: Linking TBC Humanitarian Assistance with Development Cooperation in Myanmar: - In 2017 Diakonia continued dialogue with aid partners in both Thailand and Myanmar on howreturn and reintegration of refugees can be integrated in their work. -Diakonia mapped/analysed how different CSO partners on both side of the border can contribute to a sustainable return and (re)integration. -Diakonia supported the development of a regional strategy and a programme on Migration and Refugee Return. This area seems to have been difficult in terms of acheiving clear results. One of the key reflections from Diakonia in linking humanitarian work by TBC with development programming by their local partners in both Myanmar and Thailand, is that the continuum concept is crippled by the huge gap in funding. Results area 10: Increasing support and donors to TBC -During 2017 Diakonia used social media, such as Facebook and Twitter to raise awareness of TBCs work and the refugee situation in Thailand. -Diakonia also organised meetings with Sida and MoFA in Sweden in order to seek collaboration in this transitional phase in order to find durable solutions for refugees. -Diakonia actively coordinated within the ACT-alliance to ensure that the ACT myanmar programme support return and durable solutions. It was agreed during the annual review meeting held in 2016 that result area 10 will be defined as a dialogue question rather than a result during the remaining programme period.) Change of focus During 2016 and 2017, the operations of Diakonia and TBC have changed, and have become more focused on "preparing for return" as funding for continued assistance in the camps have dwindled. So, in addition to regular activities aimed at meeting basic humanitarian needs in the camps, so called "go and see" visits to potential return sites have been supported. Around 145 villages in 15 townships in southeast Myanmar have been identified as potential return sites. ‘Go and see’ visits have been conducted to more than 60 of the villages.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
